title: Accessibility statement
heading1: Accessibility statement for the ‘Apply for probate’ service
paragraph1: This service allows users to apply for a grant of representation (also known as probate) online.
paragraph2: This website is run by HM Courts and Tribunals. We want as many people as possible to be able to use this website. For example, that means you should be able to:
list1-item1: change colours, contrast levels and fonts
list1-item2: zoom in up to 300% without the text spilling off the screen
list1-item3: navigate most of the website using just a keyboard
list1-item4: navigate most of the website using speech recognition software
list1-item5: listen to most of the website using a screen reader (including the most recent versions of JAWS, NVDA and VoiceOver)
paragraph3: We’ve also made the website text as simple as possible to understand.
paragraph4: AbilityNet has advice on making your device easier to use if you have a disability.
paragraph5: We know some parts of this website are not fully accessible:
list2-item2: some links are ambiguous when browsing out of context
list2-item3: the focus is sent to the top of the page when submitting your address
list2-item4: error summaries are not clearly stated when using screen reader technologies
list2-item5: content for error skip links and validation messages are not consistent with keyboard and screen reader technologies
list2-item6: some of the content does not enlarge when the page is magnified
list2-item7: some of the page titles do not accurately describe its topic or purpose
list2-item8: most older PDF documents are not fully accessible to screen reader software

heading4: Reporting accessibility problems with this website
paragraph8: We’re always looking to improve the accessibility of this website. If you find any problems that are not listed on this page or think we’re not meeting accessibility requirements, contact:
paragraph11: Find out about call charges
paragraph12: The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the ‘accessibility regulations’). If you’re not happy with how we respond to your complaint, contact the Equality Advisory and Support Service (EASS).
heading6: Contacting us by phone or visiting us in person
paragraph13: We provide a text relay service for people who are deaf, hearing impaired or have a speech impediment.
paragraph14: Our offices have audio induction loops, or if you contact us before your visit we can arrange a British Sign Language (BSL) interpreter.

heading7: Technical information about this website’s accessibility
paragraph19: HM Court and Tribunal is committed to making its website accessible, in accordance with the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018.
paragraph20: The website is partially compliant with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines version 2.1 AA standard, due to the non-compliances listed below.
paragraph21: The content listed below is non-accessible for the following reasons.
heading8-1: Non compliance with the accessibility regulations
list4-item1: some page content does not enlarge when the page is magnified using the pinch and zoom gesture. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 1.4.4 (resize text)
list4-item2: some form elements are present that are not descriptive of their function or purpose. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 2.4.6 (headings and labels)
list4-item3: some form fields have multiple labels. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 1.3.1 (info and relationships)
list4-item4: some page contents are presented in an illogical order. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 1.3.2 (meaningful sequence)
list4-item5: some error summaries skip links are broken. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 2.4.1 (bypass blocks)
list4-item6: focus is taken to the top of the page when an address is selected in the address field. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 2.4.3 (focus order)
list4-item7: some page titles are not unique, that it describes the pages contents. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 2.4.3 (focus order)
list4-item8: some links are present that are not descriptive of the destination or purpose in or out of context. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 2.4.4 (in context)
paragraph22: We plan to fix these issues by September 2020. When we publish new content, we’ll make sure they meet WCAG 2.1 accessibility standards.
paragraph23: Some of our interactive forms are difficult to navigate using a keyboard. For example, because some form controls are missing a ‘label’ tag.
paragraph24: Our forms are built and hosted through third party software and ‘skinned’ to look like our website. This fails WCAG 2.1 success criterion 1.3.1 (information and relationships).
paragraph25: We’ve assessed the cost of fixing the issues with navigation and accessing information, and with interactive tools and transactions. We believe that doing so now would be a disproportionate burden within the meaning of the accessibility regulations. We will make another assessment when the supplier contract is up for renewal, likely to be in 2021.
heading10: Content that’s not within the scope of the accessibility regulations
paragraph26: Many of our older PDFs and Word documents do not meet accessibility standards - for example, they may not be structured so they’re accessible to a screen reader. This does not meet WCAG 2.1 success criterion 4.1.2 (name, role value).
paragraph27: Some of our PDFs and Word documents are essential to providing our services. For example, we have PDFs with information on how users can access our services, and forms published as Word documents. By September 2020, we plan to either fix these or replace them with accessible HTML pages.
paragraph28: The accessibility regulations do not require us to fix PDFs or other documents published before 23 September 2018 if They’re not essential to providing our services.
paragraph29: Any new PDFs or Word documents we publish will meet accessibility standards.
paragraph30: Partial sections of our Probate service are hosted by third party services and are not under our control, therefor may not be fully accessible.
paragraph32: This website was last tested on 03 October 2019. The test was carried out by a third party - The Digital Accessibility Centre (DAC).
paragraph34: All issues raised during the DAC accessibility audit are currently being fixed.
heading12: What we’re doing to improve accessibility
paragraph35: We continually run automated accessibility testing as part of our development practices and resolve issues before websites and new functionality is released. We use Pa11y and Axe with our quality assurance processes.
paragraph36: We will also carry out manual internal testing throughout our daily practices.
paragraph37: This statement was prepared on 24 September 2019. It was last updated on 21 April 2020.
